Law's Empire at 176, 225176 Law's Empire

Van Roermund also rejects MacCormick's distinction between normative and narrative coherence, an sees narrative coherence as the very principle of the relation between facts and norms (case and decision), thereby relying on philosophical argu- ments. Two citations are too nice to be left unquoted. 'Facts are, as Strawson put it (1964), what statements, when true, state; they are not what statements are about... i.e., they are not things or states or events, but the objectifiable contents of state- ments'. 'This definition of"a fact" resembles...Goodman's famous phrase: "Facts are little theories; and true theories are big facts"' (1988, at 160) 160
